title: 114_hr1061
content: The "Farm to School Act of 2015" is also known as the "Farm to School Act". It aims to improve access to local foods through the Farm to School Program. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include definitions for "agricultural producer" and "eligible school", expanding the scope to include various food service programs for children. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for land-grant colleges, universities, and nonprofit entities to receive grants, technical assistance, and research support for implementing agricultural literacy and nutrition education. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for improving local food procurement and distribution options for agricultural producers and eligible schools through grants and funding for innovative approaches. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for grants under subsection (D) with a maximum amount of $200,000 and a term not exceeding 3 years. The Secretary aims to provide diverse awards to match project needs. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for grants under subsection (D) with a maximum amount of $200,000 and a term not exceeding 3 years. The grants funds must be used solely for carrying out a conference, with specific amendments to clauses related to meals and practicality. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for grants under subsection (D) with a maximum amount of $200,000 and a term not exceeding 3 years. Amendments include expanding the selection of local commodities for eligible schools and giving priority to projects using products from tribal agricultural producers for tribal community projects. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to provide technical assistance, research, and information to assist eligible schools, agencies, tribal organizations, agricultural producers, and nonprofit entities. The Farm to School Act of 2015 aims to increase awareness and participation in farm to school programs among agricultural producers, including beginning, veteran, and socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers. Additionally, a review is required one year after the enactment of the Act and every three years thereafter. The Farm to School Act of 2015 mandates a review every three years to identify and eliminate barriers to developing farm to school programs. The Secretary must submit a report to relevant committees detailing progress and regulatory compliance costs. The Farm to School Act of 2015 requires a review every three years to address barriers in farm to school programs, including regulatory compliance costs and market access for small-scale production. Funding for the Secretary is increased to $15,000,000 with a limit of 5% for administrative costs.
